title: any font similar to this
content:
please help: does anybody what type this (GALVANO-MAGNETIC...) is? do you know anything similar?

thanks in advance,  
curtze

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [galvano.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203171212/http:/typophile.com/files/galvano.png) | 42.92 KB |

 [‹ 1960s font](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203171212/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39230 "Go to previous forum topic") [Serif font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203171212/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39232 "Go to next forum topic")
author: curtze

comments.content: [Eagle](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203171212/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/font_bureau/eagle_light/?sample_text=GALVANO%20MAGNETIC&sample_size=36&acs_ss=-1&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1) is similar to it except for the M.

The G is the hardest part to match, but if you made the G from a C with about the right closure, all you need to find is a sans with a low crossbar on the A. I thought of House’s Neutraface, but if you don’t want to make that kind of investment, you could work with [Neuzeit Grotesk (Geometric 706)](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203171212/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/geometric-706/) and use a small amount of added white stroke to thin the strokes like your sample.

This is assuming you only want to do a limited amount of lettering this way.

- Mike Yanega

wow mike, neutra looks great. actually i’m using it as an inspiration for a logotype, so i’ll probably not buy a font for it, so thank you for the workaround as well ;-)

cheers,  
curtze
